messages: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (09:19): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427, also note that the spec says the values should be "on" and "off"...

042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (09:20): which spec? Ian's old spec doesn't
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (09:20): http://www.damowmow.com/playground/spellcheck.txt
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (09:22): ah, but an even older one does: http://lists.whatwg.org/pipermail/whatwg-whatwg.org/2006-June/006762.html
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (09:22): sorry for the confusion
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (09:27): http://twitter.com/nlothian/statuses/1131828648
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (09:27): (worth a read)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (09:29): wonders if @color-profile is implemented
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (09:32): http://blog.mozilla.com/rob-sayre/2009/01/19/where-memes-go-to-die/ (#7)

952fcd570c09b3137446717c00bcbdd6 (09:33): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: you may already have seen this, but: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-rdf-in-xhtml-tf/2009Jan/0075.html http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-rdf-in-xhtml-tf/2009Jan/0077.html
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (09:36): I hadn't
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (09:36): is not following public-rdf-in-xhtml-tf
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (09:37): thinks the voting Ian referred to would be in the HTMLWG, not the WHATWG

952fcd570c09b3137446717c00bcbdd6 (09:56): yeah, Manu has it wrong, in fact the whole RDFa issue is a result of misinformation and misunderstandings, we wouldn't have this issue of RDFa deployment if the W3C admited publicly that only a handfull of people are using XHTML
952fcd570c09b3137446717c00bcbdd6 (10:04): ...That way we wouldn't end up with specs that can't be implemented.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (10:09): no big deal
952fcd570c09b3137446717c00bcbdd6 (10:11): It's no big deal as long as everyone knows that HTML5 doesn't have an obligation to suport all these unimplementable specs
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (10:11): well, there is disagreement over that
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (10:12): and I think we've yet to establish who is right
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (10:16): 952fcd570c09b3137446717c00bcbdd6, which spec re rdfa are you thinking is unimplementable?
952fcd570c09b3137446717c00bcbdd6 (10:18): c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266: http://www.w3.org/TR/rdfa-syntax/

c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (10:20): that's 'rdfa in xhtml'; nobody is asking HTML5 to be XML-only. So I think this leaves the door open for figuring out which bits of it could be re-built on top of html5 without too much trauma
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (10:20): eg. a profile without using curies
952fcd570c09b3137446717c00bcbdd6 (10:21): how can you implement a spec that is XHTML only, when there's only about one hundred people in the world using XHTML
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (10:22): this conversation isn't feeling very collaborative. i'm trying to talk to you about finding a version of that design which *is* implementable in html5...
952fcd570c09b3137446717c00bcbdd6 (10:23): if you have to alter the spec to be usable in text/html, then the whole should be altered since the web is text/html, therefore the spec has no value
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (10:24): "if ... then .... therefore ...."
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (10:24): nope, you've lost me.
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (10:24): one more time?
952fcd570c09b3137446717c00bcbdd6 (10:24): start again from scratch
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (10:24): i spent some time yesterday talking with henri, and looking at existing rdfa parser behaviour
952fcd570c09b3137446717c00bcbdd6 (10:25): specs need to be written from scratch to suit text/html
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (10:25): idea was to find something that was close to what those parsers expect (i tested 6); and close to what could be done in html5 with no ugliness
952fcd570c09b3137446717c00bcbdd6 (10:26): sure, so we are really starting from scratch then, right?
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (10:26): the rdfa spec tries to be a design that can be bound to specific concrete carrier languages (svg, atom, xhtml, ...)
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (10:27): binding to a non-xml language is more of a stretch; since you need to invent or avoid having a ns abbreviation mechanism
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (10:27): most of the dicussion to date has been around this re-inventing a ns prefixing mechanism
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (10:27): the idea we explored yesterday was about avoiding one by always using full URIs
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (10:28): ie. a compromise that might not be what either 'side' wants but which can still be useful

952fcd570c09b3137446717c00bcbdd6 (10:29): I can understand that, but, not many people are using xhtml, most people using svg in the future will be using it in text/html which has no support for namespaces
952fcd570c09b3137446717c00bcbdd6 (10:31): ...and people using xhtml in the future will be using xhtml5, not xhtml1, so unfortunately that spec we mentioned has no real value
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (10:31): so would you agree it was useful for me to spend my yesterday trying out rdfa tool support for a namespaces-free profile of rdfa?
952fcd570c09b3137446717c00bcbdd6 (10:31): I think that's a step forward
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (10:32): notes are in http://svn.foaf-project.org/foaftown/2009/rdfa/tests/readme.txt if you're interested
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (10:32): unfortunately it seems the parsers mostly work on the html5 no-ns version, but so long as they find a magic hack,  xmlns:http="http:"

c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (10:33): henri said it's easier to make the validator tolerate this than to have it check real use of xml namespaces; but i hope we can approach from the other side too, and have rdf parsers not look for it
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (10:34): this would give a copy-and-paste-friendly profile of rdfa: subsets which, with some care, could be copy/pasted between html5 and xhtml5/atom/svg docs
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (10:34): (obviously you'd need to stick to pretty bland markup to avoid tripping up on other things, but that's life)

952fcd570c09b3137446717c00bcbdd6 (10:38): has the RDFa crowd got any demo pages showing what they think RDFa could look like in a html5 page? I don't understand what the need is for namespaces or pseudo non xml namespaces
952fcd570c09b3137446717c00bcbdd6 (10:41): actually, I don't think I've seen a concrete proposal put forward from the RDFa guys, I saw something about adding six attributes
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (10:42): see t5 and t6 examples in  http://svn.foaf-project.org/foaftown/2009/rdfa/tests/
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (10:42): those are what i was testing parsers with; one has xhtml boilerplate, the other htm5

c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (10:43): and http://svn.foaf-project.org/foaftown/2009/rdfa/tests/g2.html is one that breaks henri's current validation demo for html5+rdfa-minus-curies, cos it uses rev=
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (10:49): encounters a bug in the Font::TTF library
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (10:50): which is surprising because I thought it'd take much less than a day to find one
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (10:58): encounters a second bug in the Font::TTF library
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (10:58): It's not going so well now :-(
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:00): have you tried error handling yet?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:02): What kind of error handling?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:02): dunno, wrong tables, wrong set of bytes, etc.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:03): No - I'm just assuming the input is an approximately correct font
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:05): maybe I don't understand what you're doing
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:08): I'm doing http://fonts.philip.html5.org/
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:09): ah, cool
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:09): I thought you were testing font interpreters
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:10): That's just a side-effect of trying to view fonts in browsers
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (11:11): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Trying a multi-byte character doesn't work well.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:13): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: I just want ASCII to work first :-)

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:18): Currently I just want to be able to load a particular font and save it again, without it mysteriously stopping working in Firefox even though I can't see any non-trivial differences in the files
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:30): Hmm, turns out that Firefox (or whatever font library it uses on Linux) is sensitive to the ordering of the tables, which is probably violating the TTF spec
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:32): ...or maybe it isn't?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:32): I'm confused :-(
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:33): Oh, yes, I was confused
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:33): curses checksums that he forgot to update
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (11:45): we use Freetype and Pango on Linux
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:47): They seem to be working fine, and it's just my code that's being stupid
